content:
re : I have transferred from Windows 10 to Windows 11

Do you mean you had a computer using Windows 10 and you have used the upgrade option to change to Windows 11 ? OR do you mean you have two computers, old one using Windows 10 and new one using Windows 11 ?

Did you need to reinstall Thunderbird? If yes, where did you get the download/installation of thunderbird ? This is important because the official website download from this link: https://www.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/all/ would put the Profile in an easy accessible default location as mentioned in all the various Help Articles etc , but if you got the latest Thunderbird via the Windows App Store then it gets more complicated as Windows stores everything in a completely different location.

Did Thunderbird ask you to create a mail account? If yes, this tells me you are using a new profile. This info combined with previous question would tell me where it got created.

In Windows C drive, do you see a folder called 'windows.old' ? If yes - click on it to see the contents do you see this 'Thunderbird' folder this in that location:

  • C:/Users/Username/Appdata/Roaming/Thunderbird

Does that 'Thunderbird' folder contain 'Profiles' folder which has profile name folders that contain abook.sqlite files of good size ? Does the 'ImapMail' or 'Mail' folder contain mail account name folders ?
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
You can delete the files and folders using Windows File Explorer, while Thunderbird is shut down.

Go to Help > Troubleshooting Information > Profile Folder > click the button to the right to open Windows File Explorer at the profile location > find Mail\Local Folders.

You will find the files and folders there.
creator: wsmwk

content: If you are referring to columns in the message list pane, just highlight a column and drag left or right.
creator: davidsk

content:
Hi DonnyDave,

I'm sorry that I don't understand completely. You say that the messages appeared after re-starting Thunderbird, so they were downloaded successfully and they are present. But you also say that they are lost. How should one understand those two apparently contradictory statements?

"with the option to delete on the server once downloaded selected" -- Then the messages should not be on the server, but you are concerned because they are not?

Is your concern about messages not appearing at all before you re-started Thunderbird? I don't know why they did not appear at first but then appeared later. I also am not familiar with that error message. If you see it again, would you please post a screenshot of it?

One possible explanation for not seeing any messages at first even though the count of messages appeared above the message list is that you had a quick filter set. Re-starting Thunderbird removed the quick filter and showed the messages. This may not be what happened in your case. It's just a possible explanation that should not cause any concern.

And that message appeared *before* Thunderbird retrieved the one hundred messages, so it was not relevant to them?
creator: mozilla98

content:
Rick (Scooter) said
I'm sorry that I don't understand completely. You say that the messages appeared after re-starting Thunderbird, so they were downloaded successfully and they are present. But you also say that they are lost. How should one understand those two apparently contradictory statements?

On restarting Thunderbird all emails that were there prior to the downloaded emails were present. These are the ones present the last time I ran Thunderbird, a few days ago. This is what was meant by the "existing" adjective: "Having closed Thunderbird and relaunched, the folder with all the existing emails appeared." The new ones – those received in the intervening period – do not appear in the list and are not on the server either.
creator: DonnyDave

content: Many people have found that this problem is caused by their anti-virus software. Are you using anti-virus software? Have you searched the forum for solutions?
